column2: commonly known as Leamington Spa or simply Leamington  (listen)
column3: is a spa town and civil parish in Warwickshire
column4: England. Originally a small village called Leamington Priors
column5: it grew into a spa town in the 18th century following the popularisation of its water which was reputed to have medicinal qualities. In the 19th century
column6: the town experienced one of the most rapid expansions in England. It is named after the River Leam

column1: The town contains especially fine ensembles of Regency architecture
column2: particularly in parts of the Parade
column3: Clarendon Square and Lansdowne Circus.

column1: In the 2011 census Leamington had a population of 49
column2: 662. Leamington is contiguous with the neighbouring towns of Warwick and Whitnash; these form a combined urban area which in 2011 had a population of 95

column1: Formerly a small village known as Leamington Priors
column2: Leamington began to develop as a town at the start of the 19th century. It was first mentioned in the Domesday Book of 1086 as Lamintone. For 400 years
column3: the settlement was under the control of Kenilworth Priory
column4: from which the older suffix derived. Its name came from Anglo-Saxon Leman-tūn or Lemen-tūn = "farm on the River Leam". The spa waters had been known in Roman times
column5: and their rediscovery in 1784 by William Abbotts and Benjamin Satchwell led to their commercialisation
column6: with invalids beginning to resort here in 1786. Six of the seven wells were drilled for; only the original spring at the site of the Aylesford Well
column8: occurred naturally.The old village of Leamington Priors was on the southern bank of the River Leam
column9: and early development was based around this. During the early 19th century
column10: developers began concentrating the town's expansion on the land north of the river. This resulted in the Georgian centre of New Town with the Leam flowing between the two.

column2: the town's existing bath houses could not cope with the increasing visitor numbers
column3: and a syndicate was formed to build a new bath house north of the River Leam. A new saline spring was found on land close to the river
column4: belonging to Bertie Greatheed
column5: a wealthy plantation owner and landowner from Guys Cliffe
column6: and a member of the syndicate. In 1814
column7: the Royal Pump Rooms and Baths were opened on the site
column9: who also designed The Regent Hotel and the Upper Assembly Rooms in the town. Spa water can still be sampled outside the building.

column1: Leamington became a popular spa resort attracting the wealthy and famous
column2: with numerous Georgian townhouses to accommodate visitors. Construction of what is now the Parade began in sections from 1808
column3: the Regent Hotel in 1818
column4: a town hall in 1830. and the Jephson Gardens in 1834.  In 1838 Queen Victoria granted the town a 'Royal' prefix
column5: and 'Leamington Priors' was renamed 'Royal Leamington Spa'. Queen Victoria had visited the town as a Princess in 1830 and as Queen in 1858. In 1840 the Victoria Bridge was opened
column6: connecting the old and new towns
column9: and inconvenient bridge.The growth of Leamington was rapid; at the time of the first national census in 1801
column10: Leamington had a population of just 315

column1: The London and North Western Railway opened the first railway line into Leamington; a  branch line from Coventry in 1844
column2: followed by a branch to Rugby in 1851. In 1852 the Great Western Railway's main line between Birmingham
column3: Oxford and London opened through Leamington
column4: upon which the first railway station at the current location was opened.As the popularity of spa resorts declined towards the end of the 19th century
column5: the focus of Leamington's economy shifted towards becoming a popular place of residence for retired people and for members of the middle class
column6: many of whom relocated from Coventry and Birmingham. Its well off residents led to the development of Leamington as a popular place for shopping.In 1832 the town's main hospital
column9: named after philanthropist Samuel Wilson Warneford. At first a semi-private affair it was taken over by the National Health Service after the Second World War
column10: before succumbing to budget cuts and closing in 1993.

column1: Leamington is closely associated with the founding of lawn tennis. The first tennis club in the world was formed in 1872 by Major Henry Gem and Augurio Pereira who had started playing tennis in the garden of Pereira. It was located just behind the former Manor House Hotel and the modern rules of lawn tennis were drawn up in 1874 in Leamington Tennis Club.

column2: Leamington was home to the Free Czechoslovak Army; a memorial in the Jephson Gardens commemorates the bravery of Czechoslovak parachutists from Warwickshire.

column1: Leamington Spa is a town and civil parish in the Warwick District
column2: an administrative division of the county of Warwickshire. Between 1875 and 1974 Leamington was a municipal borough. As part of the 1974 local government reform it was merged with Warwick
column3: Kenilworth and Whitnash
column4: and surrounding rural areas into the Warwick District
column5: which has its offices in Leamington. In 2002 Leamington Spa became a civil parish and gained a new Town Council.Leamington is part of the parliamentary constituency of Warwick and Leamington. From the 1997 general election until the 2010 general election the constituency was represented in parliament by James Plaskitt of the Labour Party; until then this had been a Conservative safe seat
column6: counting former British prime minister Anthony Eden among its MPs. The seat became highly marginal at the 2005 general election
column7: where James Plaskitt won with a majority of just 266 votes. In the 2010 general election the seat returned to the Conservative Party
column8: with Chris White winning the seat by 3
column9: 513 votes. White remained the MP until the 2017 general election
column10: when the seat was won by Matt Western of the Labour Party.

column1: Leamington is divided by the River Leam running east to west
column2: which is susceptible to flooding in extreme weather
column3: with especially heavy floods in 1998 and 2007.The town has several parks and gardens
column4: including the Jephson Gardens
column5: close to the Royal Pump Rooms and next to the River Leam. These were seriously damaged in the floods of 1998
column6: but have been restored and improved with funding from the National Lottery. The other side of the River Leam
column7: on Priory Terrace features the "Elephant Walk" 19th-century slipway down to the river located near the suspension bridge in Jephson Gardens. It was specifically constructed so that circus elephants in winter quarters in Leamington could be watered. Other parks are the Mill Gardens on the opposite bank of the river to Jephson Gardens
column10: The Dell and Newbold Comyn which includes the nature reserves Welches Meadow and Leam Valley.The main road running through the town centre is Parade (formerly Lillington Lane until 1860). This shopping street contains high street chains and The Royal Priors shopping mall.

column1: The town has enveloped the older village of Lillington. Other suburbs include Milverton
column2: to the west and Sydenham to the southeast.

column1: The ancient town of Warwick lies adjoined directly to the west of Leamington
column2: on the opposite bank of the River Avon. Also contiguous with Leamington
column3: directly to the south
column4: with no natural border
column5: is the smaller town of Whitnash. The village of Cubbington is adjoined to the north-east. Just outside the town lie the villages of Old Milverton to the north and Radford Semele 2.5 miles (4 km) to the east.

column2: famous as William Shakespeare's birthplace and the home of the Royal Shakespeare Company
column3: lies south-west from Leamington Spa along the Warwick Road (A439).

column1: Buildings in the town include a variety of Georgian and early Victorian architecture
column2: and listed buildings such as the Grade II listed Lansdowne Crescent in neo-classical style
column3: designed by William Thomas between 1835 and 1838.Amongst the Anglican churches in Leamington is the Gothic All Saints' Church.

column1: St Mark's Church on Rugby Road was designed by Sir Giles Gilbert Scott in 1879. It is a Gothic revival design
column2: in red brick with stone dressings. It was endowed by the Carus-Wilson family
column3: in memory of Frances Carus-Wilson (d.1872)
column4: wife of Sir Trevor Wheler. There is a Roman Catholic church
column5: two United Reformed churches (one being in Lillington)
column6: a small mosque and a Hindu temple. In 2009
column7: the Sikh community built the Gurdwara Sahib Leamington and Warwick in Warwick which also serves Leamington. There are also Christadelphian and Jehovah's Witnesses meeting halls in the town.

column2: a Warwickshire Justice Centre was opened in Newbold Terrace. As well as a police station
column3: the complex houses a magistrates' court
column4: and the Crown Court
column6: and other agencies such as the Probation Service and Victim Support. It was officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II on 4 March 2011.An oak tree just to the northeast of the town centre is marked by a plaque stating that it commemorates the Midland Oak
column7: a tree that grew near the spot and was reputed to be at the centre of England.

column1: The popularity of the town's waters in the 19th century led to the town's initial growth
column2: making tourism Leamington's primary industry in the 19th century.

column1: In the town centre there are a variety of shops from high street chains to independent retailers
column2: plus an indoor shopping centre
column3: The Royal Priors. There is an out of town retail park is called the Leamington Shopping Park (formerly The Shires Retail Park)

column1: Tourism was initially driven by the spring waters. The arrival of the Warwick and Napton Canal (later amalgamated into the Grand Union Canal) officially opened in 1799 as the primary means of cargo transport and led to growth in other industries until rail gradually took over in the mid 19th century
column2: The canal supplied coal to the gasworks on Tachbrook Road
column3: providing gas to light the town from 1835. Pig iron
column4: coke and limestone were delivered by canal
column5: allowing a number of foundries to be established in Leamington
column6: specialising in cast iron stoves. Today the Eagle Foundry
column8: continues to manufacture Rangemaster Aga stoves. The Imperial Foundry
column10: was subsequently taken over by Ford
column11: casting engine blocks until its closure in 2008.The prominent car parts manufacturer Automotive Products based in the south of the town grew from a small garage to occupy a large site. Throughout the 20th century
column13: Automotive Products expanded and built a factory in the South of the town in 1928 that is still operative in 2009
column14: although on a much smaller scale. Karobes Limited
column16: was one of Britain's major suppliers of accessories for cars between World War II and the 1970s.

column1: Commercial parks for service providers and light industry and offices are primarily located to the south of the town: Althorpe Street Industrial Estate
column2: Queensway Trading Estate
column3: Shires Gate Trading Estate and Sydenham Industrial Estate.

column2: Detroit Electric announced that they would be building their SP.01 all-electric roadster in Leamington Spa.

column1: === Digital media and the video game industry ===
Leamington Spa and the surrounding area
column2: known as Silicon Spa
column3: is a significant global centre for the video game industry
column4: with a higher than average proportion of digital media companies involved in games development
column6: and over a thousand employed directly in game development. Companies based in or around the town include Third Kind Games
column23: Supersonic Software and Midoki. Codemasters are based in the countryside outside Leamington and were the initial impetus behind the cluster
column24: providing many of the staff for the companies in Leamington. In 2013
column25: Sega's mobile platform studio Hardlight Studio set up in Leamington
column26: and Exient opened a satellite studio.

column1: Former companies were Blitz Games Studios
column2: FreeStyleGames
column3: Bigbig Studios and Titus Software UK Limited.

column1: Local hospitals include the Royal Leamington Spa Rehabilitation Hospital and the Warwickshire Nuffield Hospital.

column1: Leamington is the location of the first of Warwickshire College's six sites
column2: and additionally another site is located just outside the town. The closest higher education institutions are the prestigious University of Warwick
column3: in southwestern Coventry
column4: and Coventry University. The town is particularly popular with Warwick University students seeking housing and entertainment.

column1: Leamington is also home to two national educational charities – The Smallpeice Trust and The Arkwright Scholarships Trust. They specialise in making young people aware of how STEM fields studied in school can lead to fulfilling and exciting careers in science and engineering sectors of industry.
Leamington Spa Art Gallery & Museum is located in the Royal Pump Rooms

column3: supported by workshops
column4: talks and other events.

column1: There are several local community centres.

column2: the annual free festival and celebration of alternative culture called the Peace Festival has been held in the Pump Room Gardens.

column9: 000 capacity music venue attracting national and international artists

column1: Two theatres are located in Leamington: the Spa Centre and the amateur The Loft
column2: with outdoor summer productions in Jephson Gardens. Leamington also has two cinemas: the Spa Centre and a multiplex.

column1: The Royal Leamington Spa Bowling Club in Victoria Park hosts the annual National Lawn Bowls Championships.
Leamington has been featured in a number of television series
column2: including the 1990s BBC situation comedy Keeping Up Appearances – filmed in and around the area. Notable episodes included one with Walton Hall which had footage of the actual town in them
column3: including the River Leam being featured as a fishing and boating spot. Other series include the drama Dangerfield and comedy detective series Mayo.

column1: In September 2010 scenes for a re-make of the series Upstairs

column4: and offers it to Mr. Norrell as a place to set up a magic school upon the advice of the Earl of Liverpool.

column1: Leamington Spa experiences the oceanic climate which covers most of the United Kingdom.
From Leamington's centre it is 3 miles (5 km) to the M40 motorway which links it to Birmingham and London. It is also served by the A46
column2: which links it to Coventry and Stratford-upon-Avon

column1: Leamington Spa railway station is served by the Chiltern Main Line
column2: which links London Marylebone to Birmingham Snow Hill and onwards to Kidderminster. Fast train services on this route are operated by Chiltern Railways.  Chiltern Railways also run trains via Warwick to Stratford-upon-Avon. West Midlands Trains operate local services to Birmingham and onwards to Worcester Shrub Hill. A line connecting Leamington Spa to Coventry is used by a West Midlands Trains local service to Nuneaton
column3: as well as CrossCountry who provide services to Banbury
column4: Oxford
column10: Newcastle and Edinburgh to the north.

column2: the University of Warwick and Coventry are operated by Stagecoach in Warwickshire and National Express Coventry. Services to Warwick
column3: Banbury
column4: Stratford-upon-Avon and Rugby are operated by Stagecoach in Warwickshire and by other independent companies. Coaches to locations nationally and internationally are available.

column1: Leamington's nearest international airport is Birmingham Airport. A general aviation airport and former tourist charter hub
column2: is the nearby Coventry Airport which  currently (2018) has no scheduled passenger services.

column1: The Grand Union Canal is used for recreation. This crosses the River Avon between Leamington and Warwick
column2: and then passes the town to the south
column3: parallel to the River Leam to the north. The rivers are not used for transport
column4: but there are proposals to render them navigable.

column1: there are national and local cycleways into and around Leamington.
Between 1881 and 1930 Leamington & Warwick Tramways & Omnibus Company operated between the two towns.

column4: mountaineer
column6: and occultist Aleister Crowley (1875-1947) and the pathologist Sir Bernard Spilsbury (1877–1947)Other famous people to live or have lived in Leamington include the inventor of the jet engine Frank Whittle (1907-1996) who lived in Leamington as a child
